return.comment: maximum length of the compressed data.

deflateBound.description: deflateBound returns an upper bound on the compressed size.
deflateBound.comments:
This is a stub function used when zlib does not supply the
deflateBound() implementation itself.

args.name: tree
args.comment: pointer to the looked up tree

args.comment: the repo to use when locating the tree.

args.comment: identity of the tree to locate.

args.comment: pointer to the looked up tree

git_tree_lookup_prefix.argline: git_tree **tree, git_repository *repo, const git_oid *id, unsigned int len
git_tree_lookup_prefix.description:
Lookup a tree object from the repository,
given a prefix of its identifier (short id).

git_tree_close.comments:
This is a wrapper around git_object_close()

IMPORTANT:
It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop
using a tree. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

git_tree_id.description: Get the id of a tree.

return.comment: the number of entries in the tree

git_tree_entrycount.description: Get the number of entries listed in a tree

args.name: filename
args.comment: the filename of the desired entry

return.comment: the tree entry; NULL if not found

git_tree_entry_byname.description: Lookup a tree entry by its filename

args.name: idx
args.comment: the position in the entry list

return.comment: the tree entry; NULL if not found

git_tree_entry_byindex.description: Lookup a tree entry by its position in the tree

git_tree_entry_attributes.description: Get the UNIX file attributes of a tree entry

git_tree_entry_name.description: Get the filename of a tree entry

git_tree_entry_id.description: Get the id of the object pointed by the entry

return.comment: the type of the pointed object

git_tree_entry_type.description: Get the type of the object pointed by the entry

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository where to lookup the pointed object

git_tree_entry_2object.description: Convert a tree entry to the git_object it points too.

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the written tree

git_tree_create_fromindex.description: Write a tree to the ODB from the index file
git_tree_create_fromindex.comments:
This method will scan the index and write a representation
of its current state back to disk; it recursively creates
tree objects for each of the subtrees stored in the index,
but only returns the OID of the root tree. This is the OID
that can be used e.g. to create a commit.

The index instance cannot be bare, and needs to be associated
to an existing repository.

args.name: builder_p
args.comment: Pointer where to store the tree builder

args.name: source
args.comment: Source tree to initialize the builder (optional)

git_treebuilder_create.comments:
The tree builder can be used to create or modify
trees in memory and write them as tree objects to the
database.

If the `source` parameter is not NULL, the tree builder
will be initialized with the entries of the given tree.

If the `source` parameter is NULL, the tree builder will
have no entries and will have to be filled manually.

git_treebuilder_clear.description: Clear all the entires in the builder

git_treebuilder_free.comments:
This will clear all the entries and free to builder.
Failing to free the builder after you're done using it
will result in a memory leak

return.comment: pointer to the entry; NULL if not found

git_treebuilder_get.description: Get an entry from the builder from its filename
git_treebuilder_get.comments:
The returned entry is owned by the builder and should
not be freed manually.

git_treebuilder_insert.argline: git_tree_entry **entry_out, git_treebuilder *bld, const char *filename, const git_oid *id, unsigned int attributes
git_treebuilder_insert.description: Add or update an entry to the builder
git_treebuilder_insert.comments:
Insert a new entry for `filename` in the builder with the
given attributes.

if an entry named `filename` already exists, its attributes
will be updated with the given ones.

The optional pointer `entry_out` can be used to retrieve a
pointer to the newly created/updated entry.

args.name: filename
args.comment: Filename of the entry to remove

git_treebuilder_remove.description: Remove an entry from the builder by its filename

git_treebuilder_filter.description: Filter the entries in the tree
git_treebuilder_filter.comments:
The `filter` callback will be called for each entry
in the tree with a pointer to the entry and the
provided `payload`: if the callback returns 1, the
entry will be filtered (removed from the builder).

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the written OID

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the object

git_treebuilder_write.description: Write the contents of the tree builder as a tree object
git_treebuilder_write.comments:
The tree builder will be written to the given `repo`, and
it's identifying SHA1 hash will be stored in the `oid`
pointer.

args.name: tag
args.comment: pointer to the looked up tag

args.name: repo

git_tag_lookup_prefix.description:
Lookup a tag object from the repository,
given a prefix of its identifier (short id).

git_tag_close.comments:
This is a wrapper around git_object_close()

IMPORTANT:
It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop
using a tag. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

git_tag_id.description: Get the id of a tag.

args.name: target
args.comment: pointer where to store the target

git_tag_target.description: Get the tagged object of a tag
git_tag_target.comments:
This method performs a repository lookup for the
given object and returns it

git_tag_type.description: Get the type of a tag's tagged object

git_tag_name.description: Get the name of a tag

git_tag_tagger.description: Get the tagger (author) of a tag

git_tag_message.description: Get the message of a tag

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the OID of the newly created tag. If the tag already exists, this parameter will be the oid of the existing tag, and the function will return a GIT_EEXISTS error code.

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the tag

args.name: tag_name
args.comment: Name for the tag; this name is validated for consistency. It should also not conflict with an already existing tag name

args.name: target
args.comment: Object to which this tag points. This object must belong to the given `repo`.

args.name: tagger
args.comment: Signature of the tagger for this tag, and of the tagging time

return.comment: 0 on success; error code otherwise. A tag object is written to the ODB, and a proper reference is written in the /refs/tags folder, pointing to it

git_tag_create.description: Create a new tag in the repository from an object
git_tag_create.comments:
A new reference will also be created pointing to
this tag object. If `force` is true and a reference
already exists with the given name, it'll be replaced.

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the OID of the newly created tag

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the tag

git_tag_create_frombuffer.argline:
git_oid *oid,
		git_repository *repo,
		const char *buffer,
		int force
git_tag_create_frombuffer.description: Create a new tag in the repository from a buffer

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the OID of the provided target object. If the tag already exists, this parameter will be filled with the oid of the existing pointed object and the function will return a GIT_EEXISTS error code.

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the lightweight tag

args.name: tag_name
args.comment: Name for the tag; this name is validated for consistency. It should also not conflict with an already existing tag name

args.name: target
args.comment: Object to which this tag points. This object must belong to the given `repo`.

return.comment: 0 on success; error code otherwise. A proper reference is written in the /refs/tags folder, pointing to the provided target object

git_tag_create_lightweight.description: Create a new lightweight tag pointing at a target object
git_tag_create_lightweight.comments:
A new direct reference will be created pointing to
this target object. If `force` is true and a reference
already exists with the given name, it'll be replaced.

args.name: tag_name
args.comment: Name of the tag to be deleted; this name is validated for consistency.

args.name: tag_names
args.comment: Pointer to a git_strarray structure where the tag names will be stored

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to find the tags

git_tag_list.description: Fill a list with all the tags in the Repository
git_tag_list.comments:
The string array will be filled with the names of the
matching tags; these values are owned by the user and
should be free'd manually when no longer needed, using
`git_strarray_free`.

args.name: tag_names
args.comment: Pointer to a git_strarray structure where the tag names will be stored

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to find the tags

git_tag_list_match.description:
Fill a list with all the tags in the Repository
which name match a defined pattern
git_tag_list_match.comments:
If an empty pattern is provided, all the tags
will be returned.

The string array will be filled with the names of the
matching tags; these values are owned by the user and
should be free'd manually when no longer needed, using
`git_strarray_free`.

args.name: callback
args.comment: the function to call on each file

git_status_foreach.argline: git_repository *repo, int (*callback)(const char *, unsigned int, void *), void *payload

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS or the return value of the callback which did not return 0;

git_status_foreach.description: Gather file statuses and run a callback for each one.
git_status_foreach.comments:
The callback is passed the path of the file, the status and the data pointer
passed to this function. If the callback returns something other than
GIT_SUCCESS, this function will return that value.

args.name: path
args.comment: the file to retrieve status for, rooted at the repo's workdir

git_status_file.description: Get file status for a single file

args.name: offset
args.comment: timezone offset in minutes for the time

git_signature_new.argline: const char *name, const char *email, git_time_t time, int offset

return.comment: the new sig, NULL on out of memory

git_signature_new.description:
Create a new action signature. The signature must be freed
manually or using git_signature_free

return.comment: the new sig, NULL on out of memory

git_signature_now.description:
Create a new action signature with a timestamp of 'now'. The
signature must be freed manually or using git_signature_free

return.comment: a copy of sig, NULL on out of memory

git_signature_dup.description: Create a copy of an existing signature.
git_signature_dup.comments: All internal strings are also duplicated.

args.name: walker
args.comment: pointer to the new revision walker

git_revwalk_new.description: Allocate a new revision walker to iterate through a repo.
git_revwalk_new.comments:
This revision walker uses a custom memory pool and an internal
commit cache, so it is relatively expensive to allocate.

For maximum performance, this revision walker should be
reused for different walks.

This revision walker is *not* thread safe: it may only be
used to walk a repository on a single thread; however,
it is possible to have several revision walkers in
several different threads walking the same repository.

git_revwalk_reset.description: Reset the revision walker for reuse.
git_revwalk_reset.comments:
This will clear all the pushed and hidden commits, and
leave the walker in a blank state (just like at
creation) ready to receive new commit pushes and
start a new walk.

The revision walk is automatically reset when a walk
is over.

args.name: walk
args.comment: the walker being used for the traversal.

args.name: oid
args.comment: the oid of the commit to start from.

git_revwalk_push.description: Mark a commit to start traversal from.
git_revwalk_push.comments:
The given OID must belong to a commit on the walked
repository.

The given commit will be used as one of the roots
when starting the revision walk. At least one commit
must be pushed the repository before a walk can
be started.

args.name: walk
args.comment: the walker being used for the traversal.

args.name: oid
args.comment: the oid of commit that will be ignored during the traversal

git_revwalk_hide.description: Mark a commit (and its ancestors) uninteresting for the output.
git_revwalk_hide.comments:
The given OID must belong to a commit on the walked
repository.

The resolved commit and all its parents will be hidden from the
output on the revision walk.

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the oid of the next commit

args.name: walk
args.comment: the walker to pop the commit from.

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if the next commit was found; GIT_EREVWALKOVER if there are no commits left to iterate

git_revwalk_next.description: Get the next commit from the revision walk.
git_revwalk_next.comments:
The initial call to this method is *not* blocking when
iterating through a repo with a time-sorting mode.

Iterating with Topological or inverted modes makes the initial
call blocking to preprocess the commit list, but this block should be
mostly unnoticeable on most repositories (topological preprocessing
times at 0.3s on the git.git repo).

The revision walker is reset when the walk is over.

args.name: walk
args.comment: the walker being used for the traversal.

git_revwalk_sorting.description:
Change the sorting mode when iterating through the
repository's contents.
git_revwalk_sorting.comments: Changing the sorting mode resets the walker.

args.name: walk
args.comment: traversal handle to close. If NULL nothing occurs.

git_revwalk_free.description: Free a revision walker previously allocated.

git_revwalk_repository.description:
Return the repository on which this walker
is operating.

args.name: repository
args.comment: pointer to the repo which will be opened

git_repository_open.comments:
The 'path' argument must point to an existing git repository
folder, e.g.

	/path/to/my_repo/.git/	(normal repository)
						objects/
						index
						HEAD

	/path/to/bare_repo/		(bare repository)
					objects/
					index
					HEAD

The method will automatically detect if 'path' is a normal
or bare repository or fail is 'path' is neither.

args.name: repository
args.comment: pointer to the repo which will be opened

args.name: git_dir
args.comment: The full path to the repository folder e.g. a '.git' folder for live repos, any folder for bare Equivalent to $GIT_DIR. Cannot be NULL.

args.name: git_object_directory
args.comment: The full path to the ODB folder. the folder where all the loose and packed objects are stored Equivalent to $GIT_OBJECT_DIRECTORY. If NULL, "$GIT_DIR/objects/" is assumed.

args.name: git_index_file
args.comment: The full path to the index (dircache) file Equivalent to $GIT_INDEX_FILE. If NULL, "$GIT_DIR/index" is assumed.

args.name: git_work_tree
args.comment: The full path to the working tree of the repository, if the repository is not bare. Equivalent to $GIT_WORK_TREE. If NULL, the repository is assumed to be bare.

git_repository_open2.description: Open a git repository by manually specifying all its paths

args.name: repository
args.comment: pointer to the repo which will be opened

args.name: git_dir
args.comment: The full path to the repository folder e.g. a '.git' folder for live repos, any folder for bare Equivalent to $GIT_DIR. Cannot be NULL.

args.name: object_database
args.comment: A pointer to a git_odb created & initialized by the user (e.g. with custom backends). This object database will be owned by the repository and will be automatically free'd. It should not be manually free'd by the user, or this git_repository object will become invalid.

args.name: git_index_file
args.comment: The full path to the index (dircache) file Equivalent to $GIT_INDEX_FILE. If NULL, "$GIT_DIR/index" is assumed.

args.name: git_work_tree
args.comment: The full path to the working tree of the repository, if the repository is not bare. Equivalent to $GIT_WORK_TREE. If NULL, the repository is assumed to be bare.

git_repository_open3.description:
Open a git repository by manually specifying its paths and
the object database it will use.

args.name: repository_path
args.comment: The user allocated buffer which will contain the found path.

args.name: start_path
args.comment: The base path where the lookup starts.

args.name: across_fs
args.comment: If true, then the lookup will not stop when a filesystem device change is detected while exploring parent directories.

args.name: ceiling_dirs
args.comment: A GIT_PATH_LIST_SEPARATOR separated list of absolute symbolic link free paths. The lookup will stop when any of this paths is reached. Note that the lookup always performs on start_path no matter start_path appears in ceiling_dirs ceiling_dirs might be NULL (which is equivalent to an empty string)

git_repository_discover.argline: char *repository_path, size_t size, const char *start_path, int across_fs, const char *ceiling_dirs
git_repository_discover.description:
Look for a git repository and copy its path in the given buffer. The lookup start
from base_path and walk across parent directories if nothing has been found. The
lookup ends when the first repository is found, or when reaching a directory
referenced in ceiling_dirs or when the filesystem changes (in case across_fs
is true).
git_repository_discover.comments:
The method will automatically detect if the repository is bare (if there is
a repository).

return.comment: a pointer to the object db

git_repository_database.description: Get the object database behind a Git repository

args.name: index
args.comment: Pointer where to store the index

return.comment: 0 on success; error code if the index could not be opened

git_repository_index.description: Open the Index file of a Git repository
git_repository_index.comments:
This returns a new and unique `git_index` object representing the
active index for the repository.

This method may be called more than once (e.g. on different threads).

Each returned `git_index` object is independent and suffers no race
conditions: synchronization is done at the FS level.

Each returned `git_index` object must be manually freed by the user,
using `git_index_free`.

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository handle to close. If NULL nothing occurs.

git_repository_free.comments:
Note that after a repository is free'd, all the objects it has spawned
will still exist until they are manually closed by the user
with `git_object_close`, but accessing any of the attributes of
an object without a backing repository will result in undefined
behavior

args.name: repo_out
args.comment: pointer to the repo which will be created or reinitialized

args.name: is_bare
args.comment: if true, a Git repository without a working directory is created at the pointed path. If false, provided path will be considered as the working directory into which the .git directory will be created.

git_repository_init.description: Creates a new Git repository in the given folder.
git_repository_init.comments:
TODO:
- Reinit the repository
- Create config files

return.comment: 1 if HEAD is detached, 0 if i'ts not; error code if there was an error.

git_repository_head_detached.description: Check if a repository's HEAD is detached
git_repository_head_detached.comments:
A repository's HEAD is detached when it points directly to a commit
instead of a branch.

return.comment: 1 if the current branch is an orphan, 0 if it's not; error code if therewas an error

git_repository_head_orphan.description: Check if the current branch is an orphan
git_repository_head_orphan.comments:
An orphan branch is one named from HEAD but which doesn't exist in
the refs namespace, because it doesn't have any commit to point to.

return.comment: 1 if the repository is empty, 0 if it isn't, error code if the repository is corrupted

git_repository_is_empty.description: Check if a repository is empty
git_repository_is_empty.comments:
An empty repository has just been initialized and contains
no commits.

args.name: id
args.comment: The ID of the path to return

return.comment: absolute path of the requested id

git_repository_path.description: Get one of the paths to the repository
git_repository_path.comments:
Possible values for `id`:

GIT_REPO_PATH: return the path to the repository
GIT_REPO_PATH_INDEX: return the path to the index
GIT_REPO_PATH_ODB: return the path to the ODB
GIT_REPO_PATH_WORKDIR: return the path to the working
	directory

return.comment: 1 if the repository is empty, 0 otherwise.

git_repository_is_bare.description: Check if a repository is bare

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repository for which to get the config

args.name: user_config_path
args.comment: Path to the user config file

args.name: system_config_path
args.comment: Path to the system-wide config file

git_repository_config.argline:
git_config **out,
	git_repository *repo,
	const char *user_config_path,
	const char *system_config_path
git_repository_config.description: Retrieve the relevant configuration for a repository
git_repository_config.comments:
By default he returned `git_config` instance contains a single
configuration file, the `.gitconfig' file that may be found
inside the repository.

If the `user_config_path` variable is not NULL, the given config
file will be also included in the configuration set. On most UNIX
systems, this file may be found on `$HOME/.gitconfig`.

If the `system_config_path` variable is not NULL, the given config
file will be also included in the configuration set. On most UNIX
systems, this file may be found on `$PREFIX/etc/gitconfig`.

The resulting `git_config` instance will query the files in the following
order:

- Repository configuration file
- User configuration file
- System configuration file

The method will fail if any of the passed config files cannot be
found or accessed.

The returned `git_config` instance is owned by the caller and must
be manually free'd once it's no longer on use.

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer to the new remote object

git_remote_get.argline: struct git_remote **out, struct git_config *cfg, const char *name
git_remote_get.description: Get the information for a particular remote

return.comment: a pointer to the fetch refspec or NULL if it doesn't exist
a pointer to the push refspec or NULL if it doesn't exist

git_remote_connect.description: Open a connection to a remote
git_remote_connect.comments: The transport is selected based on the URL

git_remote_ls.description: Get a list of refs at the remote
git_remote_ls.comments: The remote (or more exactly its transport) must be connected.

git_remote_free.description: Free the memory associated with a remote

args.name: refname
args.comment: the name of the reference to check

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on successful match; GIT_ENOMACH on match failure or an error code on other failure

git_refspec_src_match.description: Match a refspec's source descriptor with a reference name

args.name: out
args.comment: where to store the target name

args.name: name
args.comment: the name of the reference to transform @preturn GIT_SUCCESS, GIT_ESHORTBUFFER or another error

git_refspec_transform.argline: char *out, size_t outlen, const git_refspec *spec, const char *name
git_refspec_transform.description: Transform a reference to its target following the refspec's rules

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repository to look up the reference

args.name: name
args.comment: the long name for the reference (e.g. HEAD, ref/heads/master, refs/tags/v0.1.0, ...)

git_reference_lookup.description: Lookup a reference by its name in a repository.
git_reference_lookup.comments:
The generated reference is owned by the repository and
should not be freed by the user.

args.name: ref_out
args.comment: Pointer to the newly created reference

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where that reference will live

git_reference_create_symbolic.argline: git_reference **ref_out, git_repository *repo, const char *name, const char *target, int force
git_reference_create_symbolic.comments:
The reference will be created in the repository and written
to the disk.

This reference is owned by the repository and shall not
be free'd by the user.

If `force` is true and there already exists a reference
with the same name, it will be overwritten.

args.name: ref_out
args.comment: Pointer to the newly created reference

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where that reference will live

args.name: id
args.comment: The object id pointed to by the reference.

git_reference_create_oid.argline: git_reference **ref_out, git_repository *repo, const char *name, const git_oid *id, int force
git_reference_create_oid.description: Create a new object id reference.
git_reference_create_oid.comments:
The reference will be created in the repository and written
to the disk.

This reference is owned by the repository and shall not
be free'd by the user.

If `force` is true and there already exists a reference
with the same name, it will be overwritten.

return.comment: a pointer to the oid if available, NULL otherwise

git_reference_oid.description: Get the OID pointed to by a reference.
git_reference_oid.comments: Only available if the reference is direct (i.e. not symbolic)

return.comment: a pointer to the name if available, NULL otherwise

git_reference_target.description: Get full name to the reference pointed by this reference
git_reference_target.comments: Only available if the reference is symbolic

git_reference_type.description: Get the type of a reference

return.comment: the full name for the ref

git_reference_name.description: Get the full name of a reference

git_reference_resolve.comments:
Thie method iteratively peels a symbolic reference
until it resolves to a direct reference to an OID.

If a direct reference is passed as an argument,
that reference is returned immediately

git_reference_owner.description: Get the repository where a reference resides

args.name: target
args.comment: The new target for the reference

git_reference_set_target.description: Set the symbolic target of a reference.
git_reference_set_target.comments:
The reference must be a symbolic reference, otherwise
this method will fail.

The reference will be automatically updated in
memory and on disk.

args.name: id
args.comment: The new target OID for the reference

git_reference_set_oid.description: Set the OID target of a reference.
git_reference_set_oid.comments:
The reference must be a direct reference, otherwise
this method will fail.

The reference will be automatically updated in
memory and on disk.

git_reference_rename.comments:
This method works for both direct and symbolic references.
The new name will be checked for validity and may be
modified into a normalized form.

The refernece will be immediately renamed in-memory
and on disk.

git_reference_delete.comments:
This method works for both direct and symbolic references.

The reference will be immediately removed on disk and from
memory. The given reference pointer will no longer be valid.

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where the loose refs will be packed

git_reference_packall.description: Pack all the loose references in the repository
git_reference_packall.comments:
This method will load into the cache all the loose
references on the repository and update the
`packed-refs` file with them.

Once the `packed-refs` file has been written properly,
the loose references will be removed from disk.

WARNING: calling this method may invalidate any existing
references previously loaded on the cache.

args.name: array
args.comment: Pointer to a git_strarray structure where the reference names will be stored

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to find the refs

args.name: list_flags
args.comment: Filtering flags for the reference listing.

git_reference_listall.description:
Fill a list with all the references that can be found
in a repository.
git_reference_listall.comments:
The listed references may be filtered by type, or using
a bitwise OR of several types. Use the magic value
`GIT_REF_LISTALL` to obtain all references, including
packed ones.

The string array will be filled with the names of all
references; these values are owned by the user and
should be free'd manually when no longer needed, using
`git_strarray_free`.

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to find the refs

args.name: list_flags
args.comment: Filtering flags for the reference listing.

args.name: callback
args.comment: Function which will be called for every listed ref

args.name: payload
args.comment: Additional data to pass to the callback

git_reference_foreach.argline: git_repository *repo, unsigned int list_flags, int (*callback)(const char *, void *), void *payload
git_reference_foreach.description: Perform an operation on each reference in the repository
git_reference_foreach.comments:
The processed references may be filtered by type, or using
a bitwise OR of several types. Use the magic value
`GIT_REF_LISTALL` to obtain all references, including
packed ones.

The `callback` function will be called for each of the references
in the repository, and will receive the name of the reference and
the `payload` value passed to this method.

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_reflog_read.description: Read the reflog for the given reference
git_reflog_read.comments:
The reflog must be freed manually by using
git_reflog_free().

args.name: oid_old
args.comment: the OID the reference was pointing to

git_reflog_write.argline: git_reference *ref, const git_oid *oid_old, const git_signature *committer, const char *msg

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_reflog_write.description: Write a new reflog for the given reference
git_reflog_write.comments:
If there is no reflog file for the given
reference yet, it will be created.

`oid_old` may be NULL in case it's a new reference.

`msg` is optional and can be NULL.

git_reflog_entrycount.description: Get the number of log entries in a reflog

return.comment: the entry; NULL if not found

git_reflog_entry_byindex.description: Lookup an entry by its index

return.comment: the new oid at this time

git_reflog_entry_committer.description: Get the committer of this entry

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: str
args.comment: input hex string; must be pointing at the start of the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes needed for an oid encoded in hex (40 bytes).

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if valid; GIT_ENOTOID on failure.

git_oid_fromstr.description: Parse a hex formatted object id into a git_oid.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: str
args.comment: input hex string of at least size `length`

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if valid; GIT_ENOTOID on failure.

git_oid_fromstrn.description: Parse N characters of a hex formatted object id into a git_oid
git_oid_fromstrn.comments:
If N is odd, N-1 characters will be parsed instead.
The remaining space in the git_oid will be set to zero.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: raw
args.comment: the raw input bytes to be copied.

git_oid_fromraw.description: Copy an already raw oid into a git_oid structure.

args.name: str
args.comment: output hex string; must be pointing at the start of the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes needed for an oid encoded in hex (40 bytes). Only the oid digits are written; a '\\0' terminator must be added by the caller if it is required.

git_oid_fmt.description: Format a git_oid into a hex string.

args.name: str
args.comment: output hex string; must be pointing at the start of the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes needed for an oid encoded in hex (41 bytes). Only the oid digits are written; a '\\0' terminator must be added by the caller if it is required.

git_oid_pathfmt.description: Format a git_oid into a loose-object path string.
git_oid_pathfmt.comments:
The resulting string is "aa/...", where "aa" is the first two
hex digitis of the oid and "..." is the remaining 38 digits.

return.comment: the c-string; NULL if memory is exhausted. Caller must deallocate the string with free().

git_oid_allocfmt.description: Format a git_oid into a newly allocated c-string.

args.name: out
args.comment: the buffer into which the oid string is output.

args.name: n
args.comment: the size of the out buffer.

return.comment: the out buffer pointer, assuming no input parameter errors, otherwise a pointer to an empty string.

git_oid_to_string.description: Format a git_oid into a buffer as a hex format c-string.
git_oid_to_string.comments:
If the buffer is smaller than GIT_OID_HEXSZ+1, then the resulting
oid c-string will be truncated to n-1 characters. If there are
any input parameter errors (out == NULL, n == 0, oid == NULL),
then a pointer to an empty string is returned, so that the return
value can always be printed.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

git_oid_cpy.description: Copy an oid from one structure to another.

args.name: len
args.comment: the number of hex chars to compare

git_oid_ncmp.argline: const git_oid *a, const git_oid *b, unsigned int len
git_oid_ncmp.description:
Compare the first 'len' hexadecimal characters (packets of 4 bits)
of two oid structures.

args.name: min_length
args.comment: The minimal length for all identifiers, which will be used even if shorter OIDs would still be unique.

git_oid_shorten_new.comments:
The OID shortener is used to process a list of OIDs
in text form and return the shortest length that would
uniquely identify all of them.

E.g. look at the result of `git log --abbrev`.

return.comment: the minimal length to uniquely identify all OIDs added so far to the set; or an error code (<0) if an error occurs.

git_oid_shorten_add.description:
Add a new OID to set of shortened OIDs and calculate
the minimal length to uniquely identify all the OIDs in
the set.
git_oid_shorten_add.comments:
The OID is expected to be a 40-char hexadecimal string.
The OID is owned by the user and will not be modified
or freed.

For performance reasons, there is a hard-limit of how many
OIDs can be added to a single set (around ~22000, assuming
a mostly randomized distribution), which should be enough
for any kind of program, and keeps the algorithm fast and
memory-efficient.

Attempting to add more than those OIDs will result in a
GIT_ENOMEM error

args.name: out
args.comment: location to store the database pointer, if opened. Set to NULL if the open failed.

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if the database was created; otherwise an error code describing why the open was not possible.

git_odb_new.description: Create a new object database with no backends.
git_odb_new.comments:
Before the ODB can be used for read/writing, a custom database
backend must be manually added using `git_odb_add_backend()`

args.name: out
args.comment: location to store the database pointer, if opened. Set to NULL if the open failed.

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if the database opened; otherwise an error code describing why the open was not possible.

git_odb_open.description:
Create a new object database and automatically add
the two default backends:
git_odb_open.comments:
- git_odb_backend_loose: read and write loose object files
	from disk, assuming `objects_dir` as the Objects folder

- git_odb_backend_pack: read objects from packfiles,
	assuming `objects_dir` as the Objects folder which
	contains a 'pack/' folder with the corresponding data

args.name: odb
args.comment: database to add the backend to

args.name: priority
args.comment: Value for ordering the backends queue

git_odb_add_backend.description: Add a custom backend to an existing Object DB
git_odb_add_backend.comments:
The backends are checked in relative ordering, based on the
value of the `priority` parameter.

Read <odb_backends.h> for more information.

args.name: odb
args.comment: database to add the backend to

args.name: priority
args.comment: Value for ordering the backends queue

git_odb_add_alternate.description:
Add a custom backend to an existing Object DB; this
backend will work as an alternate.
git_odb_add_alternate.comments:
Alternate backends are always checked for objects *after*
all the main backends have been exhausted.

The backends are checked in relative ordering, based on the
value of the `priority` parameter.

Writing is disabled on alternate backends.

Read <odb_backends.h> for more information.

args.name: db
args.comment: database pointer to close. If NULL no action is taken.

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer where to store the read object

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the object to read.

return.comment: - GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read; - GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database.

git_odb_read.description: Read an object from the database.
git_odb_read.comments:
This method queries all available ODB backends
trying to read the given OID.

The returned object is reference counted and
internally cached, so it should be closed
by the user once it's no longer in use.

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer where to store the read object

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: short_id
args.comment: a prefix of the id of the object to read.

git_odb_read_prefix.argline: git_odb_object **out, git_odb *db, const git_oid *short_id, unsigned int len

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read; GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database. GIT_EAMBIGUOUS if the prefix is ambiguous (several objects match the prefix)

git_odb_read_prefix.description:
Read an object from the database, given a prefix
of its identifier.
git_odb_read_prefix.comments:
This method queries all available ODB backends
trying to match the 'len' first hexadecimal
characters of the 'short_id'.
The remaining (GIT_OID_HEXSZ-len)*4 bits of
'short_id' must be 0s.
'len' must be at least GIT_OID_MINPREFIXLEN,
and the prefix must be long enough to identify
a unique object in all the backends; the
method will fail otherwise.

The returned object is reference counted and
internally cached, so it should be closed
by the user once it's no longer in use.

args.name: len_p
args.comment: pointer where to store the length

args.name: type_p
args.comment: pointer where to store the type

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the object to read.

return.comment: - GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read; - GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database.

git_odb_read_header.description:
Read the header of an object from the database, without
reading its full contents.
git_odb_read_header.comments:
The header includes the length and the type of an object.

Note that most backends do not support reading only the header
of an object, so the whole object will be read and then the
header will be returned.

args.name: db
args.comment: database to be searched for the given object.

return.comment: - 1, if the object was found - 0, otherwise

git_odb_exists.description: Determine if the given object can be found in the object database.

args.name: oid
args.comment: pointer to store the OID result of the write

args.name: odb
args.comment: object database where to store the object

args.name: data
args.comment: buffer with the data to storr

args.name: type
args.comment: type of the data to store

git_odb_write.argline: git_oid *oid, git_odb *odb, const void *data, size_t len, git_otype type
git_odb_write.description: Write an object directly into the ODB
git_odb_write.comments:
This method writes a full object straight into the ODB.
For most cases, it is preferred to write objects through a write
stream, which is both faster and less memory intensive, specially
for big objects.

This method is provided for compatibility with custom backends
which are not able to support streaming writes

args.name: stream
args.comment: pointer where to store the stream

args.name: db
args.comment: object database where the stream will write

args.name: size
args.comment: final size of the object that will be written

args.name: type
args.comment: type of the object that will be written

git_odb_open_wstream.argline: git_odb_stream **stream, git_odb *db, size_t size, git_otype type

return.comment: 0 if the stream was created; error code otherwise

git_odb_open_wstream.description: Open a stream to write an object into the ODB
git_odb_open_wstream.comments:
The type and final length of the object must be specified
when opening the stream.

The returned stream will be of type `GIT_STREAM_WRONLY` and
will have the following methods:

	- stream->write: write `n` bytes into the stream
	- stream->finalize_write: close the stream and store the object in
		the odb
	- stream->free: free the stream

The streaming write won't be effective until `stream->finalize_write`
is called and returns without an error

The stream must always be free'd or will leak memory.

@see git_odb_stream

args.name: stream
args.comment: pointer where to store the stream

args.name: db
args.comment: object database where the stream will read from

args.name: oid
args.comment: oid of the object the stream will read from

return.comment: 0 if the stream was created; error code otherwise

git_odb_open_rstream.description: Open a stream to read an object from the ODB
git_odb_open_rstream.comments:
Note that most backends do *not* support streaming reads
because they store their objects as compressed/delta'ed blobs.

It's recommended to use `git_odb_read` instead, which is
assured to work on all backends.

The returned stream will be of type `GIT_STREAM_RDONLY` and
will have the following methods:

	- stream->read: read `n` bytes from the stream
	- stream->free: free the stream

The stream must always be free'd or will leak memory.

@see git_odb_stream

git_odb_hash.argline: git_oid *id, const void *data, size_t len, git_otype type
git_odb_hash.description: Determine the object-ID (sha1 hash) of a data buffer
git_odb_hash.comments:
The resulting SHA-1 OID will the itentifier for the data
buffer as if the data buffer it were to written to the ODB.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: path
args.comment: file to read and determine object id for

args.name: type
args.comment: the type of the object that will be hashed

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if valid; error code otherwise

git_odb_hashfile.description:
Read a file from disk and fill a git_oid with the object id
that the file would have if it were written to the Object
Database as an object of the given type. Similar functionality
to git.git's `git hash-object` without the `-w` flag.

git_odb_object_close.comments:
This method must always be called once a `git_odb_object` is no
longer needed, otherwise memory will leak.

git_odb_object_id.description: Return the OID of an ODB object
git_odb_object_id.comments: This is the OID from which the object was read from

git_odb_object_data.description: Return the data of an ODB object
git_odb_object_data.comments:
This is the uncompressed, raw data as read from the ODB,
without the leading header.

This pointer is owned by the object and shall not be free'd.

git_odb_object_size.description: Return the size of an ODB object
git_odb_object_size.comments:
This is the real size of the `data` buffer, not the
actual size of the object.

git_odb_object_type.description: Return the type of an ODB object

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repository to look up the object

args.name: id
args.comment: the unique identifier for the object

git_object_lookup.argline:
git_object **object,
		git_repository *repo,
		const git_oid *id,
		git_otype type
git_object_lookup.description: Lookup a reference to one of the objects in a repostory.
git_object_lookup.comments:
The generated reference is owned by the repository and
should be closed with the `git_object_close` method
instead of free'd manually.

The 'type' parameter must match the type of the object
in the odb; the method will fail otherwise.
The special value 'GIT_OBJ_ANY' may be passed to let
the method guess the object's type.

args.name: object_out
args.comment: pointer where to store the looked-up object

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repository to look up the object

args.name: id
args.comment: a short identifier for the object

args.name: len
args.comment: the length of the short identifier

git_object_lookup_prefix.argline:
git_object **object_out,
		git_repository *repo,
		const git_oid *id,
		unsigned int len,
		git_otype type
git_object_lookup_prefix.description:
Lookup a reference to one of the objects in a repostory,
given a prefix of its identifier (short id).
git_object_lookup_prefix.comments:
The object obtained will be so that its identifier
matches the first 'len' hexadecimal characters
(packets of 4 bits) of the given 'id'.
'len' must be at least GIT_OID_MINPREFIXLEN, and
long enough to identify a unique object matching
the prefix; otherwise the method will fail.

The generated reference is owned by the repository and
should be closed with the `git_object_close` method
instead of free'd manually.

The 'type' parameter must match the type of the object
in the odb; the method will fail otherwise.
The special value 'GIT_OBJ_ANY' may be passed to let
the method guess the object's type.

git_object_id.description: Get the id (SHA1) of a repository object

git_object_type.description: Get the object type of an object

return.comment: the repository who owns this object

git_object_owner.description: Get the repository that owns this object
git_object_owner.comments:
Freeing or calling `git_repository_close` on the
returned pointer will invalidate the actual object.

Any other operation may be run on the repository without
affecting the object.

git_object_close.comments:
This method instructs the library to close an existing
object; note that git_objects are owned and cached by the repository
so the object may or may not be freed after this library call,
depending on how agressive is the caching mechanism used
by the repository.

IMPORTANT:
It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop using
an object. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

git_object_type2string.description: Convert an object type to it's string representation.
git_object_type2string.comments:
The result is a pointer to a string in static memory and
should not be free()'ed.

git_object_string2type.description: Convert a string object type representation to it's git_otype.

return.comment: true if the type represents a valid loose object type, false otherwise.

git_object_typeisloose.description: Determine if the given git_otype is a valid loose object type.

args.name: type
args.comment: object type to get its size

return.comment: size in bytes of the object

git_object__size.description:
Get the size in bytes for the structure which
acts as an in-memory representation of any given
object type.
git_object__size.comments:
For all the core types, this would the equivalent
of calling `sizeof(git_commit)` if the core types
were not opaque on the external API.

args.name: index
args.comment: the pointer for the new index

args.name: index_path
args.comment: the path to the index file in disk

git_index_open.description:
Create a new bare Git index object as a memory representation
of the Git index file in 'index_path', without a repository
to back it.
git_index_open.comments:
Since there is no ODB or working directory behind this index,
any Index methods which rely on these (e.g. index_add) will
fail with the GIT_EBAREINDEX error code.

If you need to access the index of an actual repository,
use the `git_repository_index` wrapper.

The index must be freed once it's no longer in use.

git_index_clear.description:
Clear the contents (all the entries) of an index object.
This clears the index object in memory; changes must be manually
written to disk for them to take effect.

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_read.description:
Update the contents of an existing index object in memory
by reading from the hard disk.

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_write.description:
Write an existing index object from memory back to disk
using an atomic file lock.

git_index_find.description:
Find the first index of any entries which point to given
path in the Git index.

git_index_uniq.description: Remove all entries with equal path except last added

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_add.description: Add or update an index entry from a file in disk
git_index_add.comments:
The file `path` must be relative to the repository's
working folder and must be readable.

This method will fail in bare index instances.

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_add2.description: Add or update an index entry from an in-memory struct
git_index_add2.comments:
A full copy (including the 'path' string) of the given
'source_entry' will be inserted on the index.

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_append.description: Add (append) an index entry from a file in disk
git_index_append.comments:
A new entry will always be inserted into the index;
if the index already contains an entry for such
path, the old entry will **not** be replaced.

The file `path` must be relative to the repository's
working folder and must be readable.

This method will fail in bare index instances.

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_append2.description: Add (append) an index entry from an in-memory struct
git_index_append2.comments:
A new entry will always be inserted into the index;
if the index already contains an entry for the path
in the `entry` struct, the old entry will **not** be
replaced.

A full copy (including the 'path' string) of the given
'source_entry' will be inserted on the index.

args.name: position
args.comment: position of the entry to remove

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_remove.description: Remove an entry from the index

return.comment: a pointer to the entry; NULL if out of bounds

git_index_get.description: Get a pointer to one of the entries in the index
git_index_get.comments:
This entry can be modified, and the changes will be written
back to disk on the next write() call.

The entry should not be freed by the caller.

return.comment: integer of count of current entries

git_index_entrycount.description: Get the count of entries currently in the index

return.comment: integer of count of current unmerged entries

git_index_entrycount_unmerged.description: Get the count of unmerged entries currently in the index

return.comment: the unmerged entry; NULL if not found

git_index_get_unmerged_bypath.description: Get an unmerged entry from the index.
git_index_get_unmerged_bypath.comments:
The returned entry is read-only and should not be modified
of freed by the caller.

return.comment: a pointer to the unmerged entry; NULL if out of bounds

git_index_get_unmerged_byindex.description: Get an unmerged entry from the index.
git_index_get_unmerged_byindex.comments:
The returned entry is read-only and should not be modified
of freed by the caller.

git_index_entry_stage.description: Return the stage number from a git index entry
git_index_entry_stage.comments:
This entry is calculated from the entrie's flag
attribute like this:

(entry->flags & GIT_IDXENTRY_STAGEMASK) >> GIT_IDXENTRY_STAGESHIFT

return.comment: a string explaining the error code

git_strerror.comments:
Get a string description for a given error code.
NOTE: This method will be eventually deprecated in favor
of the new `git_lasterror`.

args.name: global_config_path
args.comment: Buffer of GIT_PATH_MAX length to store the path

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if a global configuration file has been found. Its path will be stored in `buffer`.

git_config_find_global.description: Locate the path to the global configuration file
git_config_find_global.comments:
The user or global configuration file is usually
located in `$HOME/.gitconfig`.

This method will try to guess the full path to that
file, if the file exists. The returned path
may be used on any `git_config` call to load the
global configuration file.

args.name: out
args.comment: Pointer to store the config instance

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_config_open_global.comments:
Utility wrapper that calls `git_config_find_global`
and opens the located file, if it exists.

args.name: path
args.comment: where the config file is located

git_config_file__ondisk.description: Create a configuration file backend for ondisk files
git_config_file__ondisk.comments:
These are the normal `.gitconfig` files that Core Git
processes. Note that you first have to add this file to a
configuration object before you can query it for configuration
variables.

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_config_new.comments:
This object is empty, so you have to add a file to it before you
can do anything with it.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: the configuration to add the file to

args.name: priority
args.comment: the priority the backend should have

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_config_add_file.description: Add a generic config file instance to an existing config
git_config_add_file.comments:
Note that the configuration object will free the file
automatically.

Further queries on this config object will access each
of the config file instances in order (instances with
a higher priority will be accessed first).

args.name: cfg
args.comment: the configuration to add the file to

args.name: path
args.comment: path to the configuration file (backend) to add

args.name: priority
args.comment: the priority the backend should have

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_config_add_file_ondisk.description: Add an on-disk config file instance to an existing config
git_config_add_file_ondisk.comments:
The on-disk file pointed at by `path` will be opened and
parsed; it's expected to be a native Git config file following
the default Git config syntax (see man git-config).

Note that the configuration object will free the file
automatically.

Further queries on this config object will access each
of the config file instances in order (instances with
a higher priority will be accessed first).

args.name: path
args.comment: Path to the on-disk file to open

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_config_open_ondisk.description: Create a new config instance containing a single on-disk file
git_config_open_ondisk.comments:
This method is a simple utility wrapper for the following sequence
of calls:
- git_config_new
- git_config_add_file_ondisk

git_config_free.description: Free the configuration and its associated memory and files

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer to the variable where the value should be stored

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_config_get_int.description: Get the value of an integer config variable.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer to the variable where the value should be stored

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_config_get_long.description: Get the value of a long integer config variable.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer to the variable where the value should be stored

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_config_get_bool.description: Get the value of a boolean config variable.
git_config_get_bool.comments:
This function uses the usual C convention of 0 being false and
anything else true.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_config_get_string.description: Get the value of a string config variable.
git_config_get_string.comments:
The string is owned by the variable and should not be freed by the
user.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_config_set_int.description: Set the value of an integer config variable.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

args.name: value
args.comment: Long integer value for the variable

git_config_set_long.argline: git_config *cfg, const char *name, long int value

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_config_set_long.description: Set the value of a long integer config variable.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_config_set_bool.description: Set the value of a boolean config variable.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to look for the variable

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS on success; error code otherwise

git_config_set_string.description: Set the value of a string config variable.
git_config_set_string.comments:
A copy of the string is made and the user is free to use it
afterwards.

args.name: cfg
args.comment: where to get the variables from

args.name: callback
args.comment: the function to call on each variable

args.name: payload
args.comment: the data to pass to the callback

git_config_foreach.argline:
git_config *cfg,
	int (*callback)(const char *var_name, const char *value, void *payload),
	void *payload

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS or the return value of the callback which didn't return 0

git_config_foreach.description: Perform an operation on each config variable.
git_config_foreach.comments:
The callback receives the normalized name and value of each variable
in the config backend, and the data pointer passed to this function.
As soon as one of the callback functions returns something other than 0,
this function returns that value.

git_libgit2_version.description:
Return the version of the libgit2 library
being currently used.

args.name: commit
args.comment: pointer to the looked up commit

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the commit.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the commit to locate. If the object is an annotated tag it will be peeled back to the commit.

git_commit_lookup.description: Lookup a commit object from a repository.

args.name: commit
args.comment: pointer to the looked up commit

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the commit.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the commit to locate. If the object is an annotated tag it will be peeled back to the commit.

args.name: len
args.comment: the length of the short identifier

git_commit_lookup_prefix.argline: git_commit **commit, git_repository *repo, const git_oid *id, unsigned len
git_commit_lookup_prefix.description:
Lookup a commit object from a repository,
given a prefix of its identifier (short id).

git_commit_close.comments:
This is a wrapper around git_object_close()

IMPORTANT:
It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop
using a commit. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

git_commit_id.description: Get the id of a commit.

return.comment: the short message of a commit

git_commit_message_short.description: Get the short (one line) message of a commit.

git_commit_message.description: Get the full message of a commit.

git_commit_time.description: Get the commit time (i.e. committer time) of a commit.

return.comment: positive or negative timezone offset, in minutes from UTC

git_commit_time_offset.description: Get the commit timezone offset (i.e. committer's preferred timezone) of a commit.

git_commit_committer.description: Get the committer of a commit.

git_commit_author.description: Get the author of a commit.

args.name: tree_out
args.comment: pointer where to store the tree object

git_commit_tree.description: Get the tree pointed to by a commit.

return.comment: the id of tree pointed to by commit.

git_commit_tree_oid.description:
Get the id of the tree pointed to by a commit. This differs from
`git_commit_tree` in that no attempts are made to fetch an object
from the ODB.

git_commit_parentcount.description: Get the number of parents of this commit

args.name: parent
args.comment: Pointer where to store the parent commit

args.name: n
args.comment: the position of the parent (from 0 to `parentcount`)

git_commit_parent.description: Get the specified parent of the commit.

args.name: n
args.comment: the position of the parent (from 0 to `parentcount`)

return.comment: the id of the parent, NULL on error.

git_commit_parent_oid.description:
Get the oid of a specified parent for a commit. This is different from
`git_commit_parent`, which will attempt to load the parent commit from
the ODB.

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the OID of the newly created commit

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the commit

args.name: update_ref
args.comment: If not NULL, name of the reference that will be updated to point to this commit. If the reference is not direct, it will be resolved to a direct reference. Use "HEAD" to update the HEAD of the current branch and make it point to this commit

args.name: author
args.comment: Signature representing the author and the authory time of this commit

args.name: committer
args.comment: Signature representing the committer and the commit time of this commit

args.name: tree
args.comment: An instance of a `git_tree` object that will be used as the tree for the commit. This tree object must also be owned by the given `repo`.

args.name: parent_count
args.comment: Number of parents for this commit

git_commit_create.sig: git_oid *::git_repository *::const char *::const git_signature *::const git_signature *::const char *::const git_tree *::int

return.comment: 0 on success; error code otherwise The created commit will be written to the Object Database and the given reference will be updated to point to it

git_commit_create.description:
Create a new commit in the repository using `git_object`
instances as parameters.

git_commit_create_v.sig: git_oid *::git_repository *::const char *::const git_signature *::const git_signature *::const char *::const git_tree *::int
git_commit_create_v.description:
Create a new commit in the repository using a variable
argument list.
git_commit_create_v.comments:
The parents for the commit are specified as a variable
list of pointers to `const git_commit *`. Note that this
is a convenience method which may not be safe to export
for certain languages or compilers

All other parameters remain the same

@see git_commit_create

args.name: blob
args.comment: pointer to the looked up blob

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the blob.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the blob to locate.

git_blob_lookup.description: Lookup a blob object from a repository.

args.name: blob
args.comment: pointer to the looked up blob

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the blob.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the blob to locate.

args.name: len
args.comment: the length of the short identifier

git_blob_lookup_prefix.argline: git_blob **blob, git_repository *repo, const git_oid *id, unsigned int len
git_blob_lookup_prefix.description:
Lookup a blob object from a repository,
given a prefix of its identifier (short id).

git_blob_close.comments:
This is a wrapper around git_object_close()

IMPORTANT:
It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop
using a blob. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

return.comment: the pointer; NULL if the blob has no contents

git_blob_rawcontent.description: Get a read-only buffer with the raw content of a blob.
git_blob_rawcontent.comments:
A pointer to the raw content of a blob is returned;
this pointer is owned internally by the object and shall
not be free'd. The pointer may be invalidated at a later
time.

git_blob_rawsize.description: Get the size in bytes of the contents of a blob

args.name: oid
args.comment: return the id of the written blob

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository where the blob will be written. this repository cannot be bare

args.name: path
args.comment: file from which the blob will be created, relative to the repository's working dir

git_blob_create_fromfile.description:
Read a file from the working folder of a repository
and write it to the Object Database as a loose blob

args.name: oid
args.comment: return the oid of the written blob

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository where to blob will be written

args.name: buffer
args.comment: data to be written into the blob

git_blob_create_frombuffer.argline: git_oid *oid, git_repository *repo, const void *buffer, size_t len
git_blob_create_frombuffer.description: Write an in-memory buffer to the ODB as a blob

GIT_SORT_NONE.comments:
Sort the repository contents in no particular ordering;
this sorting is arbitrary, implementation-specific
and subject to change at any time.
This is the default sorting for new walkers.

GIT_SORT_TOPOLOGICAL.comments:
Sort the repository contents in topological order
(parents before children); this sorting mode
can be combined with time sorting.

GIT_SORT_REVERSE.comments:
Iterate through the repository contents in reverse
order; this sorting mode can be combined with
any of the above.

GIT_OID_RAWSZ.comments: Size (in bytes) of a raw/binary oid

GIT_OID_HEXSZ.comments: Size (in bytes) of a hex formatted oid

GIT_OID_MINPREFIXLEN.comments:
Minimum length (in number of hex characters,
i.e. packets of 4 bits) of an oid prefix

GIT_EXTERN(type).comments: Declare a public function exported for application use.

GIT_EXTERN_TLS(type).comments: Declare a public TLS symbol exported for application use.

GIT_INLINE(type).comments: Declare a function as always inlined.

GIT_FORMAT_PRINTF(a,b).comments: Declare a function's takes printf style arguments.

GIT_PATH_LIST_SEPARATOR.comments:
The separator used in path list strings (ie like in the PATH
environment variable). A semi-colon ";" is used on Windows, and
a colon ":" for all other systems.

GIT_PATH_MAX.comments: The maximum length of a git valid git path.
